awd_titl_txt: Scalable Nanomanufacturing of Hierarchical Nanometer-Scale Colloidal Assemblies Using Integrated Electrospray and Microfluidics
awd_abstract_narration:
Providing clean water and safe drug delivery are grand societal challenges.  The field of nanotechnology offers ways to address both challenges.  However, the manufacture of nanoparticles and, in particular, sub-10 nm particles needed to support these revolutionary solutions is plagued by low yield and long production times.  Conventional production of self-assembled nanomaterials is highly time consuming with poor control of structural uniformity due to undesired and uncontrolled inter-particle interactions under particle thermal fluctuation. This grant supports fundamental research to develop a scalable nanomanufacturing process for high-throughput production of nanocolloidal assemblies. The new approach that integrates rapid electrospray and microfluidic processes solves the current bottleneck in slow and low-yield manufacturing of hierarchically structured nanomaterials. The success of this research impacts U.S. manufacturing, economy, and security. This project uniquely integrates multiple disciplines including manufacturing, fluid mechanics, materials science, and device fabrication. The multidisciplinary approach helps recruit and train students, including women and underrepresented minorities, as the next generation of U.S. engineers, thus positively impacting engineering education. 

Many manufacturing approaches have utilized external fields, such as electrical and optical fields, to overcome colloidal thermal fluctuations and direct the assembly of colloidal nanoparticles. However, scalable nanomanufacturing processes to rapidly and precisely assemble nanocolloids of 10 nm or smaller size, including noble metal and metal oxide nanoclusters and (bio)polymers, remain few and challenging. This project develops an integrated electrospray and microfluidic manufacturing process to rapidly concentrate inorganic nanoclusters and polymers in droplet nanoreactors and control their hierarchical nanocolloidal assembly by dielectrophoresis. Ultrafast laser spectroscopy is integrated with the continuous microfluidic process to enable in-situ characterization of the compositions and assembly process of building hierarchical nanocolloids in liquid media. Results obtained from this research advance the fundamental understanding of nanoscale electrokinetic behavior of complex nanomaterials. Both electrospray and dielectrophoresis microfluidic modules can be linearly scaled-up to pioneer high-throughput nanomanufacturing of multi-component and structured nanocolloidal assemblies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Precise and robust control of structures and compositions of nanocolloidal assemblies into novel functional materials is economically and scientifically important to advance nanotechnology and manufacturing for a variety of applications including catalysis, nanomedicine, and energy conversion. Conventional production of self-assembled nanomaterials is highly time consuming and in poor control of their structural uniformity, due to undesired and uncontrolled inter-particle interactions under particle thermal fluctuation. This project has succeeded in bridging the gap between laboratory batch study and industrial-scale production by integrating rapid ac-electrospray and dielectrophoresis process in a microfluidic platform. This new and scalable nanomanufacturing platform can achieve high-throughput assembly of nanocolloids of 10 nm or smaller in size, including noble metal and metal oxide nanoclusters and (bio)polymers. 

This project has set to solve the current bottleneck in the slow and low manufacturing of sub-10 nm nanocolloid and polymer assemblies. The PI and her students have successfully developed an integrated ac-electrokinetic and microfluidic process to rapidly concentrate inorganic nanoclusters and polymers in droplet nanoreactors and control their hierarchical assembly by dielectrophoresis (DEP). In-situ single-molecule/particle characterization by ultrafast laser spectroscopy has advanced our mechanistic understanding of the unique relationship among composition, clustering dynamics, and hierarchical nanostructures in confined nanodomain, which is highly distinct from bulk solution assembly. We have successfully demonstrated the new nanomanufacturing process with two distinct functional nanocomposite systems. One successful application is the ac-electrospray-based coating of interfacial polymer layers on ceramic electrolyte surface and subsequent mass-production of hybrid ceramic-polymer all solid-state electrolytes with superior Li-ion conductivity for Li-ion battery application. The other example is the rapid fabrication of luminescent, flexible, and ultralong composite polymer-quantum dot (QD) nanofibers by the ac-electrospinning of their liquid-liquid separating complex coacervates for biosensing application. Results obtained from this research also advance our fundamental understanding of the ac-electrokinetic behavior of complex nanomaterials. The integrated ac-electrokinetic and microfluidic modules can be linearly scaled-up to pioneer high-throughput nanomanufacturing of multi-component and structured supramolecular assemblies for  broad applications from energy to nanomedicine. 

The project was instrumental in training one female postdoctoral researcher, two PhD students including one female student, and three undergraduate students, two of who were recruited outside the PI’s institution.

 


Last Modified: 08/20/2024
Modified by: Yingxi Elaine E Zhu
